title: Problem Introduction
content: **Erdos Problem #359** concerns MacMahon's sequence where a_1 = 1 and each a_{i+1} is the smallest integer not expressible as a sum of consecutive earlier terms. The main questions ask about the growth rate of this sequence.
mathContext: The sequence is OEIS A002048: 1, 2, 4, 5, 8, 10, 14, 15, ... Andrews conjectured a_k ~ (k log k) / (log log k). The problem remains OPEN.

title: Consecutive Sums
content: **ConsecutiveSum** computes the sum A(a) + A(a+1) + ... + A(b) of consecutive terms. Unlike subset sums, we require the terms to be contiguous.
mathContext: Defined as sum over Finset.Icc a b. The constraint of consecutive indices creates the gaps that define MacMahon's sequence.

title: Achievable Sums
content: **AchievableSums** is the set of all integers expressible as a consecutive sum from the first k+1 terms. A number is achievable if it equals some A(a) + A(a+1) + ... + A(b) with b <= k.
mathContext: This set grows as k increases. The next term A(k+1) is chosen as the smallest integer greater than A(k) that is NOT in this set.

title: IsGoodFor Predicate
content: **IsGoodFor A n** says: A(0) = n, A is strictly increasing, and each A(j+1) is the least integer greater than A(j) not achievable as a consecutive sum from A(0)...A(j).
mathContext: Uses IsLeast from Mathlib to formally capture 'smallest integer satisfying a condition'. The recursion uniquely determines the sequence given n.

title: MacMahon Sequence
content: **IsMacMahonSeq** defines THE MacMahon sequence as the unique sequence 'good for 1'. This is the sequence 1, 2, 4, 5, 8, 10, 14, 15, ... (OEIS A002048).
mathContext: Named after Percy MacMahon who studied these 'prime numbers of measurement'. The sequence has fascinating connections to combinatorics.

title: Basic Properties
content: **macmahon_first_term** shows A(0) = 1, **macmahon_strictMono** proves strict monotonicity, and **term_is_achievable** shows each A(i) is achievable as the 'singleton sum' of just itself.
mathContext: These are direct consequences of the definition. Strict monotonicity follows because A(j+1) > A(j) by construction.

title: Known Sequence Values
content: **macmahonValues** lists the first 8 terms: 1, 2, 4, 5, 8, 10, 14, 15. Note that 3, 6, 7, 9, 11, 12, 13 are all skipped because they're achievable as consecutive sums.
mathContext: 3 = 1 + 2, 6 = 2 + 4, 7 = 1 + 2 + 4, etc. The 'gaps' in the sequence reveal which sums are achievable.

title: Why 3 and 6 are Skipped
content: **three_is_achievable** proves 3 in AchievableSums (since 3 = 1 + 2 = A(0) + A(1)). **six_is_achievable** proves 6 in AchievableSums (since 6 = 2 + 4 = A(1) + A(2)).
mathContext: These verified theorems show concrete examples of the sequence's construction. Each uses the Finset.sum_Icc_succ_top lemma to compute the sum.

title: Growth Rate Conjectures (OPEN)
content: **Three open conjectures**: (1) a_k/k -> infinity (superlinear), (2) a_k/k^{1+c} -> 0 for c > 0 (subpolynomial), (3) Andrews' conjecture a_k ~ (k log k)/(log log k).
mathContext: These capture the expected intermediate growth rate - faster than linear but slower than any polynomial > 1. All remain OPEN.

title: Porubsky's Upper Bound (1977)
content: **porubsky_upper** states: for any epsilon > 0, infinitely many k satisfy a_k < (log k)^epsilon * (k log k)/(log log k). This gives partial evidence for Andrews' conjecture.
mathContext: The bound shows the sequence doesn't grow too much faster than the conjectured rate, at least infinitely often.

title: Counting Functions
content: **countingFunction** counts terms <= x, and **primeCounting** counts primes <= x. These allow comparing MacMahon's sequence to primes.
mathContext: The counting function A(x) = |{i : A(i) <= x}| measures how 'dense' the sequence is up to x.

title: Porubsky's Density Bound
content: **porubsky_density_bound** states limsup A(x)/pi(x) >= 1/log(2). MacMahon's sequence is denser than primes by at least this factor infinitely often.
mathContext: Since 1/log(2) ~ 1.44, the sequence has at least 44% more elements than primes (asymptotically, infinitely often).

title: General Starting Value
content: **general_n_superlinear** conjectures that sequences 'good for n' (starting with any n > 0) also have superlinear growth a_k/k -> infinity.
mathContext: The problem generalizes beyond n = 1. Different starting values create different sequences but with similar growth behavior.

title: Summary Theorem
content: **erdos_359_summary** bundles basic facts: A(0) = 1 for MacMahon sequences, strict monotonicity holds, and the first and eighth values are 1 and 15 respectively.
mathContext: A convenience theorem packaging the core verified results for quick reference.
